tossups.question: Two characters in this novel discuss the difference between "premeditated beauty" and "beauty by mistake". A character in this novel concludes that "either man was created in God's image - and God has intestines" or "God lacks intestines" while discussing the incompatibility of God and shit. In this novel, a man's contemplation of his wife as an "abandoned child" prompts him to pick up a translation of Sophocles. That man in this novel refers to the idea of the (*) "difficult resolution" to explain why he must leave Geneva, where he worked in exile as a surgeon. The narrator of its first part notes that the "idea of eternal return is a mysterious one" before describing how he married and got his wife a dog named Karenin. For 10 points, name this novel about Tereza and Tomas by Milan Kundera.
tossups.answer: The Unbearable Lightness of Being [or Nesnesitelná lehkost bytí]

tossups.question: In one context, this letter denotes the line integral of the transverse component of momentum as a charged particle moves between two turning points. The longitudinal adiabatic invariant of a magnetic mirror is denoted by this letter. Another quantity denoted by this letter is dotted with the electric field to give the rate at which electromagnetic fields do work in Poynting's theorem. The divergence of that quantity denoted by this letter equals minus the time derivative of the (*) charge density according to a continuity equation. To avoid confusion with electric current, electrical engineers use this letter instead of i to denote the imaginary unit. A hat over this letter denotes the Cartesian unit vector parallel to the y-axis. For 10 points, what letter symbolizes the SI unit of energy?
tossups.answer: J

tossups.question: Since telecoms in this territory were banned after its capture, communities here used to gather to talk near the "Shouting Hill". Intense "shuttle diplomacy" produced the Agreement on Disengagement regarding this territory, which was then occupied by the UNDOF observation force. The three consecutive Battles of Hermon failed to take this territory, though its chief town of Quneitra ("koo-NAY-truh") was briefly recaptured. This territory lies within a (*) buffer region demarcated by the "Purple Line" and is just east of the "Green Line" which extends around the edge of Lake Tiberias. Local Druze have largely boycotted elections in this territory, which was captured in an unauthorized offensive ordered by Moshe Dayan ("MOH-shay dah-YAHN"). For 10 points, name this plateau which Israel seized from Syria during the Six-Day War.
tossups.answer: Golan Heights [or Ramat HaGolan or Hadbat ul-Jawlan; do not accept or prompt on "Syria" or "Palestine" or "West Bank"]

tossups.question: The camera follows a swinging bell as people pray to Jesus in an early scene of a movie from this country titled Enthusiasm. Another movie from this country uses slow-motion to depict athletes jumping hurdles in a park and features a scene where a person's eye is superimposed with the opening and closing of an aperture. Its directors, including a man who compared himself to a "kino-eye", promoted the notion of individual creation as "handwriting" or faktura. The film (*) Man with a Movie Camera is from this country, whose directors developed montage theory. A close-up of a bleeding nurse and her broken glasses appears in a movie from this country that depicts a carriage rolling down the Odessa steps. For 10 points, what country's pioneering directors included Dziga ("dzee-gah") Vertov and Sergei Eisenstein?
tossups.answer: Soviet Union [or U.S.S.R.; or C.C.P.; prompt on Russia; do not accept or prompt on "Russian empire" or "Russian Federation"]

tossups.question: A solo assassin describes 25 years of his incarceration in a monoplay from this country titled Strange Lands. The first play written by an acting troupe from this country uses Brecht's gestus technique to adapt Machiavelli's The Mandrake to local circumstances, and is titled The Coat. A trio of authors from this country collaborated on a play in which the photographer Styles helps a man get a work permit by impersonating the deceased Robert. Characters remember making a (*) kite out of a tomato box in another play from this country that opens with two men practicing ballroom dancing. The founder of this country's Serpent Players wrote a play which ends with Hally spitting on Sam's face. Plays titled for Sizwe Banzi and Master Harold are from, for 10 points, what home country of Athol Fugard?
tossups.answer: South Africa [or Republic of South Africa] (The author of Strange Lands is Anton Krueger.)

tossups.question: This operation is the Hodge dual of the commutator Lie ("lee") bracket, so it also satisfies the Jacobi identity. The infinitesimal generators of rotations are given by this operation. A generalization of this operation defined on the exterior algebra is symbolized by a wedge. This operation is given by the imaginary part of the product of two imaginary quaternions; octonions give an analogous definition in (*) seven dimensions. This anticommutative operation can be written as the determinant of a 3x3 matrix with unit vectors in the first row. The magnitude of this operation applied to two adjacent edges of a parallelogram is its area. It returns zero for two parallel vectors. For 10 points, what operation returns a vector orthogonal to the two input vectors according to the right-hand rule?
tossups.answer: cross product [prompt on vector product; before "exterior", prompt on exterior product or wedge product; do not accept or prompt on "curl" or "del cross"]

tossups.question: This practice "makes falsehood truth, guilt innocence" according to an influential sermon delivered by Eliphalet Nott, who claimed that the “mighty [have] fallen” due to it. Alexander McClung, who rode a horse named “Rob Roy,” was given the epithet “Black Knight” for his involvement with this practice. Until 1862, naval officers abided by a 1777 Irish code for this practice, an instance of which led to Stephen (*) Decatur’s death. An 1804 letter by Charles Cooper to Philip Schuyler sparked one of these events in New Jersey’s Palisades. The Bowie knife was popularized following one of these events that took place at the Vidalia sandbar. Since these events were banned in New York, New Yorkers often engaged in it in Weehawken. For 10 points, Aaron Burr killed Alexander Hamilton during what sort of event?
tossups.answer: dueling [accept word forms like duels; accept code duello; prompt on killing, shooting, etc.]

tossups.question: Sacred apes live on the mountain containing the entrance to this location, which is also home to a dog-headed ape named Aani. An enigmatic part of this location has three shrines whose purpose is secret and, like another part of it, is called the Abyss of Waters. Yet another part of this location is inhabited by a bunch of fire-breathing snakes. As described in several "Books of Overthrowing", priests destroyed wax models of a figure who lives in this location to help his (*) opponent pass through this location's twelve gates. Upon leaving this location, a god becomes the scarab Khepri ("KEP-ree"). The beast Ammit lives in this location, where Set performs his only heroic action by defeating Apep. Every night, Ra's barge passes through, for 10 points, what location ruled by Osiris and inhabited by the dead?
tossups.answer: Duat [or Tuat, or Akert; accept Ancient Egyptian underworld or Ancient Egyptian afterlife; accept answers that indicate the kingdom of Osiris before "Osiris"; prompt on underworld or afterlife]

tossups.question: A deadly 1980 accident occurred when MV Summit Venture collided into a bridge spanning this body of water. In mid-January, Ye Mystic Krewe ("crew") organizes a pirate-themed festival in this body of water. This is the (emphasize) smaller of the two bodies of water that surround Hillsborough and Pinellas Counties. At a power plant in the community of Apollo Beach, many tourists come to watch West Indian manatees swim in this body of water. The Sunshine Skyway Bridge, named after governor (*) Bob Graham, spans this body of water near a non-European city named St. Petersburg. The headquarters of the Church of Scientology is located in Clearwater, a city on this body of water, which is also home to the Buccaneers football team. For 10 points, name this body of water, named after the most populous city on Florida's west coast.
tossups.answer: Tampa Bay [do not prompt on or accept "Tampa"]

tossups.question: This artist placed two wolves next to a woman who stands in a clearing wearing a single-feathered headdress, in a painting from the Trickster series titled Portrait of Mickalene Thomas, the Coyote. This artist re-imagined works by Turner, Homer, and Bosch in the series In Search of the Miraculous. A pair of Timberland boots appears in his re-creation of another painting, to which he added an ornate red background with tiny sperm and the name "Williams" next to those of (*) "Carolus Magnus" and "Hannibal". In his best-known painting, this artist of a version of Jacques-Louis David's Napoleon Crossing the Alps added chrysanthemums and jasmines to a green foliated background, representing the sitter's native Hawaii. For 10 points, name this painter of Barack Obama's official presidential portrait.
tossups.answer: Kehinde Wiley

tossups.question: Blaschke et al. showed that this compound stimulates DNA demethylation by TET enzymes. Enzymes dependent on 2-oxoglutarate and this compound downregulate HIF-1 in oxygenated cells. Converting this compound to its "dehydro" form creates a diketone from the enediol (“een-DIE-all”) group in its five-membered ring. This compound may be useful therapeutically to treat sepsis, since it supports endogenous norepinephrine (“NOR-eh-pin-EFF-rin”) production as a (*) cofactor for dopamine beta-hydroxylase. This compound reduces iron from +3 to +2 as a cofactor for the enzymatic hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Low intake of this compound can cause wound reopening and gum bleeding, since it's essential for synthesizing collagen. For 10 points, name this water-soluble vitamin whose deficiency causes scurvy.
tossups.answer: L-ascorbic acid [or L-ascorbate; accept vitamin C; accept dehydroascorbic acid, dehydroascorbate, or DHA; accept semidehydroascorbic acid, semidehydroascorbate, or SDA; accept hexuronic acid or hexuronate]

tossups.question: It’s not soma, but this substance is central to the Shingon Buddhist goma ritual, which is dedicated to the Wisdom King Acala, who is often depicted as a garuda carrying this substance. Goma is derived from an older srauta ritual using this substance called hotra. Svaha must be chanted during rituals using this substance, including one in which this substance's blessings are gained by cupping or waving the hands above it, called (*) aarti. The first Vedic hymn is dedicated to the god of this substance, which is central to yajña rituals and is circled by the couple seven times in Hindu weddings. The Hindu god of this substance has seven tongues to lick up ghee, allowing this substance to send prayers and offerings to the gods. For 10 points, name this substance embodied by Agni.
tossups.answer: fire [accept flames or other clear equivalents; do not accept or prompt on "light" or "the Sun"]

tossups.question: The use of emeralds in a group of polities named for this commodity is examined in Kris Lane's book Color of Paradise. This commodity's production, first described in writing in the treatise The Master Who Embraces Simplicity, was refined by Hassan al-Ramah. William McNeill and Marshall Hodgson theorized that monopolizing this commodity drove state centralization. Possibly thanks to learning about this commodity from the ambassador William of Rubruck, the monk Roger (*) Bacon became the first to make it in Europe. The Mughals, Safavids, and Ottomans are often grouped as the "empires" of this commodity, as it was crucial for the operation of the arquebuses ("ARK-eh-buses") they used to dominate the battlefield. China is credited with inventing, for 10 points, what substance which is ignited in the barrels of muskets?
tossups.answer: gunpowder [or black powder; accept gunpowder empire; prompt on saltpeter]

tossups.question: In the prologue to an opera by this composer, a king ignores the omen of a solar eclipse after a people's choir sings "Glory, Glory to the Radiant Sun!" In a dance from that opera by this composer, a shimmering A-major chord leads into a plagal melody introduced by a solo oboe beginning "B, B, long high F-sharp," accompanied by harp arpeggios. A tone poem by this composer begins with first violins entering two at a time playing very long sustained high Es, after which an ornamented (*) English horn solo begins, depicting a traveling caravan. In an opera this composer adapted from a medieval lay, women in a nomadic camp perform the "Gliding Dance of the Maidens". The piece In the Steppes of Central Asia is by, for 10 points, what Russian who included the "Polovtsian Dances" in Prince Igor?
tossups.answer: Alexander Porfiryevich Borodin

tossups.question: The speaker of this poet's sequel to one of his own poems describes how revolutions "set the feet above the brain and swear the brain is in the feet" and tells his grandson, "half the morning have I paced these sandy tracts". That sequel rebuts this poet's earlier vision of a world "lapt in universal law" and governed by the "Parliament of man," and is set "Sixty Years After". This poet wrote "In the Spring a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love" about a young soldier who bids (*) "Comrades, leave me here a little," before recalling how his cousin Amy rejected him at the title childhood home. The title soldiers of another poem by this author of "Locksley Hall" say "ours not to reason why / ours but to do and die". For 10 points, name this poet of "The Charge of the Light Brigade".
tossups.answer: Alfred, Lord Tennyson (The sequel is "Locksley Hall Sixty Years After.")

tossups.question: These people's movement to new islands marks the last major expansion of the Q-branch of the broader language family to which they belong, as opposed to the P-branch. An English corruption of a term from these people's namesake language, "septs," denotes their family units; another such corruption produced the term "gallowglass," denoting elite mercenaries from those among them who intermingled with the Norse. These people migrated to new lands during the 6th century expansion of the kingdom of Dál Riada ("dahl REE-uh-duh"), which reached the (*) Isle of Skye and the coast of Argyll ("AR-ghyle"). They later merged with the Picts under King Kenneth I to form the Kingdom of Alba, which ruled the highlands. For 10 points, name this group of Celtic people originating from Ireland, whose namesake language has "Scots" and "Irish" varieties.
tossups.answer: Gaels [or Gaelic people, or Goidels, or Goidelic people; prompt on Celts or Celtic people before "Celts"; prompt on Irish or Scots by asking "to what ethno-linguistic group do they belong?"]

tossups.question: Augmented Dickey-Fuller unit root tests are commonly used to examine persistence in this economic statistic in Europe, such as in a June 2020 working paper by Jordi Gali which proposes policies to alleviate "insider-outsider" markets. Olivier Blanchard and Larry Summers explained such persistence in this statistic via hysteresis. Leading New Keynesian theories hold that volatility in this non-monetary statistic is limited by nominal price rigidity, which is a form of (*) stickiness. It's plotted against the vacancy rate on a Beveridge Curve. Keeping this statistic near its "natural rate" and as low as sustainably possible is part of the "dual mandate" of the Federal Reserve. Cyclical, structural, and frictional changes drive most fluctuations in, for 10 points, what statistic that measures the jobless rate?
tossups.answer: unemployment rate [accept jobless rate before "jobless"]

tossups.question: The degree to which this quantity causes a change in volume is measured by a "contraction coefficient" denoted beta. This dimensionless variable is one of the two quantities transferred via surface and deep fluxes in Henry Stommel's two-box model. This quantity is held at a reference value of 35 when calculating the specific volume anomaly. This quantity is often reported in "practical units" when it is calculated from electric conductivity measurements, which use (*) potassium chloride as a standard. Gradients in temperature and this quantity drive a set of global currents called the thermohaline circulation. This quantity is higher for brine than it is for brackish water. For 10 points, what measurement of dissolved solid content is high for seawater, but low for freshwater?
tossups.answer: salinity [accept salt content or salt concentration or clear equivalents thereof]

tossups.question: The U.S. and British editions of this publication, both launched by Hachette Filipacchi in 1985, were bought out by Hearst in 2011. In 1995, the editor-in-chief of this publication suffered a stroke that left him with locked-in syndrome, inspiring his book The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. Its flagship publication has twice profiled the author of Sex and Lies and The Perfect Nanny, Leïla Slimani; in 2019, its US edition profiled the transgender actress Indya Moore. (*) Hélène Gordon-Lazareff founded this magazine, whose U.S. publication is currently edited by Nina Garcia, and whose flagship Paris publication is owned by Lagardère ("lah-gar-DARE"). An annual set of Style Awards are presented by, for 10 points, what most widely circulated culture and fashion magazine in the world, whose name is the French word for "she"?
tossups.answer: Elle [accept Elle Style Awards]

tossups.question: A work in this literary genre recounts how its author bought a farm in Haddam Neck, Connecticut and carried a 9-pound axe. While staying in an attic, the narrator of another work in this genre recounts her "loophole of retreat". Works in this genre include one by Venture Smith and one in which Nathan Johnson suggests that the protagonist take a surname from Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake. In another work in this genre, Benjamin serves as a role model for the pseudonymous (*) Linda Brent. Mr. Covey tries to "break" the protagonist of a work in this genre who is taught how to read by Sophia, the daughter of the oppressive Mr. Auld, before escaping from Maryland to New York and founding The North Star. For 10 points, give this genre of memoirs by Harriet Jacobs and Frederick Douglass.
tossups.answer: slave narratives [accept obvious equivalents; prompt on memoirs or narratives or autobiography]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about music under the Third Reich:
answers: Paul Hindemith ("HIN-duh-mit") (The opera is Mathis der Maler.)
parts: This conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic under the Third Reich led an infamous 1942 performance of Beethoven's Ninth for Hitler's birthday.

Furtwängler nonetheless championed this composer, whose works were banned by the Nazis in 1936. His best-known opera opens with an "Angelic Concert" in which bright G major chords clash with rising G minor figures played by the woodwinds.

Werner Egk's ("VAIR-nur ek'z") opera based on this Henrik Ibsen play was met with Hitler and Goebbels's approval. Edvard Grieg's incidental music to this play includes the piece "In the Hall of the Mountain King".

bonuses.leadin: Practitioners of this tradition may curse an individual to be haunted by a malevolent remnant of an earthly soul called a duppy. For 10 points each:
answers: obeah [or obi, or obeya, or obia]
Kongo people [or BaKongo, MuKongo, EsiKongo, or MwisiKongo; accept Kingdom of Kongo, Kongo dia Ntotila, Wene wa Kongo, or Reino do Congo]
parts: Name this form of folk healing and sorcery based on Akan and Igbo practices. It's most widespread in Jamaica.
Obeah is sometimes called the "Jamaican" version of this syncretic religion widely practiced in Haiti, which venerates Bondye ("bone-DYEH") and loas ("LWAH'z").

The related but distinct Jamaican tradition of myal, which focuses on spiritual connection rather than magic, is rooted in the native religion of this African people. Their namesake kingdom converted to Catholicism under Afonso I, born Mvemba a Nzinga.

bonuses.leadin: This collection contains a story in which Jack the Ripper prowls a futuristic "City at the Edge of the World". For 10 points each:
answers: auto-da-fés [or autos-da-fé; prompt on inquisitions or trials]
parts: Name this pioneering 1967 anthology of New Wave science fiction stories compiled by Harlan Ellison. Many of its entries went on to win Hugo and Nebula awards.
This author of the short story "Nightfall" and the Foundation trilogy wrote the foreword to Dangerous Visions.

Dangerous Visions includes a story by Roger Zelazny titled for these events, in which futuristic bullfights feature human "mechadors" who fight cars. In Candide, Pangloss survives a hanging during one of these events held after the Lisbon earthquake.

bonuses.leadin: The "radius" named for this technology is used in calculations with non-circular cross-sections. For 10 points each:
answers: cross-sectional area AND the wetted perimeter
parts: Name this general type of technology whose theoretical underpinning is Pascal's principle. Modern automobile brakes and namesake "presses" use this technology, which involves using fluids to transmit and modify forces.
The hydraulic radius of a conduit is defined as the ratio of these two quantities characterizing the geometry of the cross-section. Give both.
In robotics, hydraulics are often used to power these components. This term describes components of a machine that create the motion.

bonuses.leadin: This politician established his country's "Eight Principles" for foreign aid after his landmark tour of Africa from 1963 to 1964. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this politician whose tour laid the groundwork for the Second Africa-Asia Conference in Algiers, the intended successor to the earlier Bandung Conference where this man stole the show.
This African leader was almost assassinated during Zhou's 1964 meeting with him. He had earlier attended the Bandung Conference representing the Gold Coast.
Zhou ended his Africa tour by speaking before a rally in this African capital city. A U.S. operation here was the subject of the movie Black Hawk Down.

bonuses.leadin: Tim Jenison attempts to recreate this painting using a camera obscura in a Penn & Teller documentary. For 10 points each:
answers: The Music Lesson, Woman Seated at a Virginal [or A Lady at the Virginals with a Gentleman; do not prompt or accept "Lady Seated at a Virginal" or "Lady Standing at a Virginal"]
Jan Vermeer van Delft [or Johannes Vermeer]
parts: Name this painting, which is set in a blue-and-white tiled room. A white jug sits on a multicolored rug to the right of a man instructing a woman in this painting.
This Dutch artist's The Music Lesson is one of his many paintings of women playing virginals. He's best known for Girl with a Pearl Earring.

Paintings in this genre appear on the virginal's interior in Vermeer's paintings of ladies "seated" and "standing" at virginals. Joachim Patinir ("YO-ah-keem PAH-tih-neer") invented a variety of this genre popular in the Renaissance.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about countries whose highest points are not on their mainland:
answers: Republic of Equatorial Guinea [or República de Guinea Ecuatorial]
parts: The highest point in Dutch territory is Mount Scenery on this island. Due to its rocky coastline, this island once only had a single point of entry - a set of 800 hand-carved steps called "The Ladder".
This archipelago's Mount Teide ("teh-EE-day"), found on its island of Tenerife ("teh-neh-REE-fay"), is both the highest point in Spanish territory and the highest point on any Atlantic archipelago.

This country's highest point is Pico Basilé ("PEE-koh bah-see-LAY") on the island of Bioko. The name of this country's island of Annobón is derived from Portuguese, even though this African country's official language is Spanish.

bonuses.leadin: After her 2002 death, Title IX was renamed in honor of this politician. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Hawaiian politician, who worked with Birch Bayh to pass Title IX in 1972. In 1964, this politician became the first Asian-American woman to serve in Congress.
In 1965, Mink introduced the first federal child-care bill to Congress, which was a part of this set of Lyndon Johnson programs that sought to eliminate racial injustice and poverty.

Mink and a congresswoman from this state, Bella Abzug, travelled to Paris to help resume the Paris Peace Accords. Abzug failed to primary Daniel Moynihan in the 1976 race to become this state's senator.

bonuses.leadin: This poem alludes to dictators' ability to stir up the public saying "Exiled Thucydides knew / All that a speech can say / About Democracy." For 10 points each:
answers: W. H. Auden [or Wystan Hugh Auden]
commencements [or graduations; accept Victory Commencement or Kenyon Commencement] (The second clue is from "This is Water" by David Foster Wallace.)
parts: Name this poem which seeks to "undo the folded lie" by declaring "We must love one another or die".
"September 1, 1939" is this author's poem about the start of World War II. He wrote "stop all the clocks" to open his poem "Funeral Blues".

Auden wrote his poem "Under Which Lyre" in response to a "Victory" example of these events held after World War II. An essay originally presented at one of these events begins with an anecdote about two fish to explain how "obvious, important realities" are among the "hardest to see".

bonuses.leadin: Arnold Beckman invented the first electrochemical device for measuring this quantity. For 10 points each:
answers: pH [or the power of hydrogen; accept acidity or basicity]
parts: Name this quantity, which is measured somewhat qualitatively by dipping litmus paper into a solution and observing the color change.
This material is used to make the working electrode in electrochemical pH meters. Indium tin oxide is a commonly-used conductive coating for this material.

This quantity can introduce errors in electrochemical pH measurements. It is the difference in electric potential that results from ion diffusion when two electrolytic solutions with different concentrations are placed in contact.

bonuses.leadin: The term for the creation of these entities, synoecism ("sih-NOH-eh-siz-um"), refers to the joining of demes ("deemz") into a single unit. For 10 points each:
answers: polis [or poleis; accept polises even though that's not the correct plural; prompt on city or city-state; do not accept or prompt on "town"]
parts: Give the Greek term for these entities whose formation marks the beginning of the Archaic period, and of which there were over 1,000 by the Classical period. Examples include Megara and Miletus.
This polis attributed its synoecism to its legendary king Theseus, who joined all the towns of nearby Attica into one political unit.

Unlike most poleis ("poh-lay-EES"), this city-state's synoecism is firmly dated to 471 B.C. by Strabo. The judges of the Olympic games, or Hellanodikai ("hel-lah-NOH-dee-kye"), were picked from citizens of this nearby polis.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some things in medicine that are classically described as "cherry-red":
answers: epiglottis (The second sentence refers to aspiration pneumonia.)
parts: Tay-Sachs and Niemann-Pick disease can produce a "cherry-red" spot on this structure, which contains a high proportion of cone cells. The fovea lies within this structure.

Infection by Haemophilus influenzae can result in a "cherry-red" or "thumbprinting" appearance of this structure. Klebsiella and anaerobes may cause a form of pneumonia characterized by the malfunction of this structure.
The skin is described as "cherry-red" in poisonings due to this gas, which binds to hemoglobin with an affinity 200 times greater than that of oxygen.

bonuses.leadin: This author's first novel, An Open Swimmer, ends with Jerra dropping a match into a burning fuel tank. For 10 points each:
answers: riders [accept The Riders or Riders in the Chariot or Riders of the Purple Sage]
parts: Name this contemporary Australian author who described the travails of the working-class Pickle and Lamb families in the novel Cloudstreet.
Winton's novels Shallows deals with the commerce in these animals. In another novel, a white one is pursued by Captain Ahab.

In Winton's novel titled for this noun, Jennifer fails to join her family in their move to Ireland. It's also the first title noun of a Peter Carey novel whose characters experience visions of Ezekiel, as well as a Zane Grey novel about the Withersteen family.

bonuses.leadin: The Provo movement attacked Claus van Amsberg, the spouse of this royal, for being a former Hitler Youth member. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this monarch, who abdicated her country’s monarchy in 2013 in favor of her son, Willem-Alexander. During her reign, Aruba seceded from her country.
Beatrix, the granddaughter of Queen Wilhelmina, was the queen of this country. Its major shipping port of Rotterdam was subjected to massive bombing during World War II.

Roel van Duyn, the founder of Provo, credits the offshoot group “Baastards” with leading the first Dutch protest against this conflict. Harold Wilson sent the Davies Mission to attempt to negotiate an end to this conflict.

bonuses.leadin: One example of this relationship is found between the Classical Arabic word for "sound judgement" and the Hebrew word for "impudence". For 10 points each:
answers: false friends [or fauxs amis; prompt on false cognates]
doublets [accept etymological twins or twinlings; prompt on twins]
parts: Name these words that have a common etymological origin, often from a shared parent language, such as the English night and the German Nacht.

This informal term denotes words which appear to be cognates and may be related, but have totally different meanings; a common example is the English embarrassed and the Spanish embarazada ("em-bah-rah-SAH-dah"), which means "pregnant".
This term denotes cognates within the same language that may have meanings that are slightly or even totally different, such as ward and guard.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the Chinese photographer Fan Ho:
answers: Hong Kong [or HKSAR, or Hong Kong Special Administrative Region]
shadows [accept Approaching Shadow or In Praise of Shadows]
parts: Ho was a major practitioner of this sort of photography, which involves taking candid photos in the namesake public places. It was pioneered by Henri Cartier-Bresson.
Ho made his name taking street photos of this city. For the book Architecture of Density, Michael Wolf took photos of this city's skyscrapers, which include Central Plaza and the HSBC building.

Ho created his most iconic photograph, titled for an "Approaching" one of these objects, by editing a photo of his cousin so that a triangular-shaped one begins at her feet. These objects title several photo books by Hiroshi Sugimoto, one of which was inspired by an essay about "violent" artificial lighting.

bonuses.leadin: Classical Latin writers often rendered this Greek word using the analogous Latin notion of a genius. For 10 points each:
answers: Septuagint [or Septuaginta; or E Metáphrasis ton Hebdomékonta; accept versio septuaginta interpretum; prompt on Greek Old Testament]
Zoroastrianism [or Zoroastrian religion; prompt on Mazdaism]
parts: Give this Greek term for figures including Nomos and Eusebia, who personified law and piety, respectively. It was later used to translate the term for "idol" in the Hebrew Bible.
The term daimon was first used for evil spirits and idols in this oldest extant Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible, whose name refers to its supposed 72 translators.
Similarly, this religion uses the term daeva, which once referred to common gods and spirits, to denote evil beings. It contrasts them with the venerated ahuras, such as Ahura Mazda.

bonuses.leadin: Hans Bethe's derivation of the Lamb shift calculated the difference in this quantity between a free electron and an electron bound to a proton. For 10 points each:
answers: self-energy of the electron [prompt on self-energy or self-interaction; prompt on mass of the electron or effective mass of the electron]
polarization [accept polarized or vacuum polarization; do not accept or prompt on "polarizability"]
parts: Name this quantity, whose one-loop Feynman diagram is a horizontal solid line, with a wavy line branching off the solid line on the left, then rejoining it on the right.
The self-energy of the (emphasize) photon causes the vacuum to transiently acquire this property. This property's "density" equals the induced dipole moment per unit volume.
A self-energy term appears in precise calculations of the mass of these very light leptons, which "oscillate" between three flavors.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about medieval proofs of the existence of God:
answers: cosmological argument [or causal argument; accept kalam cosmological argument]
argument from degree [or degrees argument, or henological argument]
parts: This argument, which holds that a "necessary existent" created all contingent things, was developed extensively by scholars in the kalam tradition. It argues that God serves as the "prime mover" in the universe.
This Archbishop of Canterbury wrote the Proslogion, which advances the ontological argument for God's existence.

The fourth of Thomas Aquinas's five proofs from the Summa Theologica is this argument, which states that since all beings have different levels of perfection, there must be one being which is absolutely perfect, and that is God.

bonuses.leadin: In one play, a character of this ethnicity named Andrew is visited in his sleep by his dead grandmother, the title "Golden Child". For 10 points each:
answers: Chinese-American [or Han Chinese; prompt on Asian-American]
M. Butterfly [do not accept or prompt on "Madame Butterfly"]
parts: Give this ethnicity of immigrant characters in many of David Henry Hwang's plays. It's also the ethnicity of Maxine Hong Kingston.
Hwang is best known for this play about the civil servant René Gallimard, who falls in love with the opera singer Song Liling, who disguises herself as a man.

In this other Hwang play, the character Hwang casts a white man named Marcus as an Asian in the play Face Values. This play itself was inspired by the casting of Jonathan Pryce in an Asian role for Miss Saigon.
